image.altText: a woman with a black top holding a phone

props.synopsis: Hundreds of coin collectors forwent the late night revelry of New Year's Eve in favour of an early morning visit to the Royal Australian Mint in Canberra, hoping to get their hands on the highly-sought-after first coin of the year.

title.children: Australia mints world's first coins for the year after ballot

image.altText: A large concrete structure with ventilation and a mural of Australian animals.

props.synopsis: Sewage is known to produce a 'rotten egg' like smell, which utilities companies employ a range of measures to stop from being released onto the streets.

title.children: If left alone, sewer pipes could stink out cities with 'rotten egg' smells

image.altText: A young man sitting on the sand at a beach wearing a parka

props.synopsis: NSW Police say search efforts for Hadi Nazari, who has been missing for six days in the Kosciuszko National Park, involves specialist bushwalkers in steep vegetated terrain.

title.children: Search continues for missing bushwalker in 'most rugged terrain' in NSW

image.altText: a close-up of a person holding a glass under a running tap, filling it with water

props.synopsis: Expecting to need another water source by the end of next decade, Canberra's water authority is considering whether the city will need to supplement the drinking water supply with purified treated sewage water in the future.

title.children: Authorities consider supplementing drinking water with treated sewage water

image.altText: a river with a warning sign

props.synopsis: The man was swimming in the Murrumbidgee River at Pine Island with family and friends when he experienced trouble in the water and failed to resurface on Sunday afternoon.

title.children: 21-year-old man drowns at popular Canberra river swimming spot

image.altText: Nick Kyrgios closes his eyes and claps his hand

props.synopsis: Nick Kyrgios is one of the most entertaining tennis players on the planet. In his singles defeat to Giovanni Mpetshi Perricard, he showed his ability as a player, too.

title.children: Nick Kyrgios the player underlines his quality even in defeat

image.altText: A street sign with four street names on it pointing in four different directions.

props.synopsis: While many of Canberra's suburbs and streets are unsurprisingly named after prime ministers and pioneers, there are some quirky exceptions and places that have taken on double meanings.

title.children: New Canberra suburb street names to strike more of a gender balance

image.altText: a woman sitting on an outdoor couch in a brightly-patterned top next to a brown border collie

props.synopsis: It's a far from uncommon situation. But what can you actually do if the neighbour's dog just won't stop barking?

title.children: How to deal with a neighbour's nuisance barking dog (and keep things cordial)

image.altText: A bush stone-curlew sits in a grassy field wearing a tiny GPS tracker backpack.

props.synopsis: Originally a community idea to reintroduce bush stone-curlews in Canberra, the project has now grown and expanded to Victoria where the birds are being successfully reintroduced with the help of tiny handmade backpacks.

title.children: 'Nice, even and snug': The tiny backpacks key to bush stone-curlew survival

image.altText: Watch Sydney's midnight New Year's Eve fireworks.

props.synopsis: Australians welcomed in 2025 in colourful style, with revellers enjoying fireworks displays in capital cities, while many in regional areas marked the new year with parties and family gatherings.

title.children: Australia celebrates the new year with spectacular fireworks, hopes for 2025

image.altText: Two men stand on the edge of a huge erosion site in Africa.

props.synopsis: The world's growing population is putting pressure on its arable land, and scientists warn 90 per cent of all soil could be degraded by 2050 unless urgent action is taken.

title.children: Planet could 'cease to function' without action to address soil decay

image.altText: Australian passports

props.synopsis: Here's all you need to know about new passport prices for Australians starting from January 1.

title.children: Rise in cost of Australian passports to $412 slammed as 'a backdoor tax grab' by LNP

image.altText: Police divers arrive at Emu Creek to search for missing water tuber

props.synopsis: A woman has died after she fell into fast-moving water while using an inflatable tube at a creek near Colinton, north-west of Brisbane, on New Year's Eve.

title.children: Woman found dead after extensive search of Queensland creek

image.altText: A young man in a blue jacket and jeans runs his hands through his hair.

props.synopsis: The world's top-ranked chess player has returned to the World Blitz Championship after its governing body agreed to loosen its dress code.

title.children: Magnus Carlsen returns to championship after rule change allows him to wear jeans

image.altText: An ocean with bright blue bioluminescence in the waves with an orange sunset in the background.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's south-eastern ocean is experiencing a rare bioluminescent red algal bloom that bursts into vibrant blue at night time. A biologist warns that the dazzling colours may indicate an imbalance in the environment.

title.children: Waves of 'glowing' algae washing ashore in Tasmania, pointing to ecological change

image.altText: The wreckage of a black car is crushed underneath a large refrigerated truck in an image taken at night.

props.synopsis: Connect Logistics will never pay the fines it received following the April 2020 tragedy on the Eastern Freeway because it has been liquidated.

title.children: Trucking company will never pay $2.3m fine over crash that killed four police

image.altText: close up of oil tanker that reads Eagle S on the side of the boat, a smaller police boat is in front of it

props.synopsis: Finnish investigators probing the damage to a Baltic Sea power cable say they found an anchor drag mark on the seabed, apparently from a Russia-linked vessel that has already been seized.

title.children: Finnish police find anchor drag marks near damaged Baltic power cables

image.altText: People in beachside bars watch a sun set over the ocean

props.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has shared his condolences for Adelaide man Jacob Vennix who died in Bali while on honeymoon. His wife Kimberley Fuller has described him as "the most beautiful human, partner and father".

title.children: Tributes for Adelaide man Jacob Vennix who died on honeymoon in Bali

image.altText: Jhye Richardson looks on in Australian training kit

props.synopsis: Jhye Richardson last played a Test more than three years ago, but says he will be ready to go in Sydney if Mitchell Starc is forced out with an injury.

title.children: Richardson in frame for SCG call-up, despite ongoing injury recovery

image.altText: A composite image of Donald Trump holding his fist up, moo deng the pygmy hippo and Taylor Swift blowing a kiss.

props.synopsis: Can you answer all our questions about last year's biggest stories and key moments correctly? See how close you get to a perfect score.

title.children: Moo Deng, the Eras Tour and more — how much do you remember about 2024?

image.altText: Man with a grey beard leaning next to a saw sharpening bench in a workshop.

props.synopsis: The WA government insists its native timber logging ban was well planned and timber towns are now thriving, but others say they are falling through the cracks.

title.children: Big divide remains in timber towns, a year after native logging ban

image.altText: Empty iron ore wagons on train tracks in bushland near Kalgoorlie.

props.synopsis: WA's Yilgarn region has been home to iron ore mining on and off since the 1950s, but the final trainload of the steel-making ingredient has arrived at Esperance Port.

title.children: End of an era as last train from WA iron ore mine arrives at port

image.altText: Black and white photo of people standing in train carts.

props.synopsis: Broken Hill's Picnic Train Attack is a "harrowing story" about two men opening fire on 1,200 civilians, killing four people. But was it Australia's first terrorist attack or an act of personal vengeance?

title.children: Terrorism or vengeance? Historians re-examine Picnic Train Attack

image.altText: Stephen Fry wears a black tie at the 68th annual tony awards in 2014

props.synopsis: More than 1,200 people in politics, sport, the arts and community service are recognised on King Charles's New Year's Honours list.

title.children: Stephen Fry and UK Post Office scandal victims in king's honours list

image.altText: A police mug shot of George Howard

props.synopsis: Thief and "extremely bad character" George Howard was part of a gang that blew up safes in several states. His daring escape from two Victorian jails had police on the back foot.

title.children: The career criminal who escaped from Victoria's toughest jails twice

image.altText: A woman holds onto a pole while riding on public transport.

props.synopsis: Payal Kapadia's romantic drama is a film about three nurses living and working in Mumbai and the complex relationships they have with desire and what that says about the expectations placed on women in India.

title.children: This award-winning movie tackles traditions and taboos in modern India

image.altText: Freakshow circus

props.synopsis: Since 1987, the annual Woodford Folk Festival has been a mecca for sharing music and stories. Now its organisers are launching a fundraiser to secure the event for future generations and fulfil its vision.

title.children: After 40 years, Woodford's famous festival enters a new era

image.altText: An apartment block surrounded by trees.

props.synopsis: Apartment owners in the Brisbane suburb of St Lucia fear a new development nearby will lower their property prices, but urban planners say housing affordability is more important.

title.children: Lower home values a fair price for more housing, planner says

image.altText: A crate full of orange lobsters.

props.synopsis: For the first time since 2020, shipments of live western rock lobsters are finally on their way to China after the trading giant lifted its ban on the prized seafood.

title.children: Western rock lobster shipments head to China for first time in four years

image.altText: Paddington Bear holds a closed umbrella and leans on a rock with mountains in the background.

props.synopsis: Paddington 2 was always going to be a hard act to follow, but the beloved bear's new adventure in the Amazon proves Paddington movies will always have their place.

title.children: Olivia Colman and Antonio Banderas join Paddington in his latest adventure

image.altText: Sri Lankan soccer player Jack Hingert walks, wearing a black polo top with a Sri Lanka football logo.

props.synopsis: Jack Hingert has won two A-League Championships, played under Ange Postecoglou and alongside Liverpool legend Robbie Fowler. But nothing has meant more than representing Sri Lanka, the country of his father.

title.children: How a Brisbane Roar legend became Sri Lanka's newest goalscorer

image.altText: A burning press van next to a hospital, with two firemen attempting to put out the blaze.

props.synopsis: The Israeli military has conducted operations against hospitals in Gaza in the last few days, drawing condemnation from numerous organisations.

title.children: UN releases report condemning Israeli attacks on Gaza hospitals

image.altText: Angelina Jolie wearing a black dress standing next to Brad Pitt in a black suit and tie in front of a black poster backdrop

props.synopsis: The Hollywood actors have come to a settlement agreement after more than eight years of legal negotiations over assets and custody of the couple's six children.

title.children: Angelina Jolie and Brad Pitt reach divorce deal after eight-year battle

image.altText: Wayne Goss claims victory in 1989 Qld election

props.synopsis: Confidential cabinet minutes, released today after 30 years, shed light on some of the key decisions made by the second-term Labor government led by Wayne Goss.

title.children: Queensland archives release 1994 Labor Goss government cabinet papers

image.altText: Uluru under yellow bluish early morning skies with sunrise streaking across surrounding national park scrub and plants

props.synopsis: Never-before-seen NT cabinet records from 1994, released to the public for the first time, show cultural tourism, women's equality and Aboriginal employment were among the issues high on the agenda.

title.children: Why a Daryl Somers tourism ad was a sign of the times for NT politics in 1994
